**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31; G.L..proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION OF CUSTODY ORDER  **Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209 § 37; and applicable Massachusetts case law**

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and when modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 & 31**.proposition: This request is supported by the authority granted under **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31**, **G.L. c. 209 § 37**, and **G.L. c. 208 § 34**, providing for modification of custody judgments based upon material change in circumstances.

**G.L. c. 209 \u00a7 37**.proposition: This request is supported by the authority granted under **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31**, **G.L. c. 209 § 37**, and **G.L. c. 208 § 34**, providing for modification of custody judgments based upon material change in circumstances.

**G.L. c. 208 \u00a7 34**.proposition: This request is supported by the authority granted under **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31**, **G.L. c. 209 § 37**, and **G.L. c. 208 § 34**, providing for modification of custody judgments based upon material change in circumstances.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the child's best interests are the paramount consideration in all custody matters. *See* **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the governing standard for removal and custody determinations in terms of the child’s best interests, calling them the ‘paramount concern’ and explaining that the statutory ‘upon cause shown’ language means removal must be in the child’s best interests. Although the case’s main focus is removal, that analysis is embedded in a broader custody context and treats the child’s best interests as the controlling consideration, thus supporting the proposition that Massachusetts courts regard the child’s best interests as paramount in custody matters.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt:
“The less strict standard, sometimes called the ‘real advantage’ standard, has been followed with variations in most jurisdictions which have considered the issue. As most recently reformulated … the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

“The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly traces the history of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in Massachusetts custody law and reaffirms that it remains the governing, paramount standard in custody determinations. It quotes Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas for the proposition that the best interests of the children are always the paramount concern, and then applies that standard in deciding the custody dispute, thereby supporting the claimed proposition about Massachusetts courts’ consistent use of the best‑interests standard as paramount in custody matters.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)…. The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider….”}

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the child's best interests are the paramount consideration in all custody matters. *See* **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the removal analysis under G. L. c. 208, § 30 in terms of whether removal is in “the best interests” of the children and repeatedly treats that best-interests inquiry as controlling. The court affirms the trial judge’s decision because she “appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children” and holds that “cause shown” in the removal statute means a showing that removal is in the child’s best interests, confirming that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in this custody-related context.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not…be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth…without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… On the facts in this case, the judge appropriately considered the ‘best interests’ of the children, and did not abuse her discretion in concluding that removal…would not serve their best interests.”

**Adoption of Vito**, 431 Mass. 550 (200.proposition: Where evidence suggests instability, substance misuse, or any behavior posing risk to a child’s safety, the Court has the authority and obligation to adjust custody or visitation arrangements. *See* **Adoption of Vito**, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
**Adoption of Vito**, 431 Mass. 550 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns termination of parental rights and the equitable power to order postadoption contact; it does not address a court’s authority or obligation to adjust custody or visitation in response to instability, substance misuse, or safety risks in an ongoing custody/visitation setting. The mother’s substance abuse and unfitness are discussed as grounds for terminating her parental rights, not as a basis for modifying existing custody or visitation orders. Thus, the case does not stand for the broad proposition about adjusting custody/visitation when risk is shown.
**Adoption of Vito**, 431 Mass. 550 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Parental unfitness in termination proceedings must be established by clear and convincing evidence… The judge concluded that Vito’s biological mother cannot now resume care and custody of Vito because ‘she has not secured adequate stable housing, has not adequately addressed her issues of lengthy substance abuse history and has not acquired any meaningful parenting skills training.’ … We conclude… the judge’s order denying the petition to dispense with parental consent to adoption is vacated… and direct that a decree enter granting the department’s petition to dispense with parental consent to Vito’s adoption.”

**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.proposition: Where evidence suggests instability, substance misuse, or any behavior posing risk to a child’s safety, the Court has the authority and obligation to adjust custody or visitation arrangements. *See* **Adoption of Vito**, 431 Mass. 550 (2000); **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that domestic violence and its effects on the child are fundamental factors that must be explicitly considered in custody determinations, and it remands because the trial judge failed to adequately account for the risks to the child before awarding custody. While the facts here concern domestic violence rather than substance misuse, the court clearly affirms the authority and obligation of courts to adjust custody or visitation based on behaviors that pose risks to a child’s safety and well‑being. Thus it supports the broader proposition that courts must respond to such risk-indicating evidence in custody/visitation orders.
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

**R.H. v. B.F.**, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (.proposition: The Court must evaluate current parental capabilities in light of the child’s welfare. *See* **R.H. v. B.F.**, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995); **Custody of a Minor**, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).
**R.H. v. B.F.**, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (.support_reasoning: The court makes clear that custody determinations must be based on the child’s best interests and criticizes the trial judge for failing to evaluate how the father’s history of domestic violence and parenting behavior affected the child. It expressly requires detailed findings showing that the effects of domestic violence on the child and on the parent’s parenting ability have been evaluated, and that any custody award to an abusive parent advances the child’s best interests. This aligns with the proposition that courts must assess current parental capabilities in light of the child’s welfare.
**R.H. v. B.F.**, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (.relevant_excerpt: “Instead, custody orders and judgments are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child, and the statutes leave it to the trial judge to identify and weigh any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the specific dispute.… We conclude that in cases where, as here, there is credible evidence of physical abuse…a trial judge must make detailed and precise findings of fact which demonstrate that the effects of the domestic violence on the child have been evaluated and…how such an award advances the best interests of the child.”

**Custody of a Minor**, 383 Mass. 595 (1.proposition: The Court must evaluate current parental capabilities in light of the child’s welfare. *See* **R.H. v. B.F.**, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (1995); **Custody of a Minor**, 383 Mass. 595 (1981).
**Custody of a Minor**, 383 Mass. 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames parental unfitness in relational terms, focusing on the effect of the parent’s conduct and capabilities on “this particular child’s welfare” rather than abstract parental shortcomings. The court treats the mother’s inability or refusal to address the serious psychological problems with the child, and the harm a return would cause, as “tantamount to a finding of unfitness in relation to the furtherance of this particular child’s welfare,” thereby requiring an evaluation of current parental capabilities in light of the child’s welfare.
**Custody of a Minor**, 383 Mass. 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: “A finding of parental unfitness may be predicated on the circumstances within a particular family, as they adversely affect the particular child, without regard to the general quality of parental conduct per se. ‘It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself.’ … Moreover, [the judge’s conclusions] are tantamount to a finding of unfitness in relation to the furtherance of this particular child’s welfare.”

**Williams v. Massa**, 431 Mass. 619 (20.proposition: A change based on substance abuse and household instability has repeatedly been found sufficient to warrant modification of custody or parenting conditions. *See* **Williams v. Massa**, 431 Mass. 619 (2000); **Costa v. Costa**, 422 Mass. 551 (1996); **Guardianship of Estelle**, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007).
**Williams v. Massa**, 431 Mass. 619 (20.support_reasoning: Williams v. Massa concerns initial custody and division of marital property in a divorce; it does not involve a post‑judgment modification of custody or parenting conditions based on newly arisen substance abuse or household instability. The custody discussion focuses on the mother’s limited insight, alienating behavior, and mental health concerns, but not on substance abuse, nor on the legal standard for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 beyond a procedural point that changes must proceed by complaint for modification. Thus it does not substantively support the proposition that such changes have ‘repeatedly been found sufficient’ to warrant modification.
**Williams v. Massa**, 431 Mass. 619 (20.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

**Guardianship of Estelle**, 70 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion in Guardianship of Estelle does not address substance abuse or household instability as grounds for modifying custody or parenting conditions. Instead, it focuses on the constitutional requirement of a parental unfitness finding before custody can be awarded to non-parents, and on balancing parental fitness with the child’s best interests and bonding with guardians. Because substance abuse and household instability are not discussed as bases for a change in custody, the case does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
**Guardianship of Estelle**, 70 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: "Custody of a child belongs to a parent unless that parent is unfit... The question, then, is how to balance a parent’s capacity to care adequately for a child (i.e., his or her ‘fitness’) with that child’s ‘best interests,’ given the child’s current circumstances... [I]f returning custody to the [biological] parent[] would be seriously detrimental to the welfare of the child, then the parent[] could be considered to be unfit."
